'''Wilfred Arthur Charles Carter''' (December 18, 1904<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> – December 5, 1996),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/ef2f0327486eb4c0f8a77eed19ca4f3c|title=Country Music Star Wilf Carter Dead at 91|website=Apnews.com|access-date=August 5, 2021}}</ref> professionally known as '''Wilf Carter''' in his native Canada and also as '''Montana Slim''' in the United States, was a Canadian [[Country music|Country]] and [[Western music (North America)|Western]] singer, songwriter, guitarist, and [[Yodeling|yodeller]]. He wrote over 500 songs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.traditionalmusic.co.uk/country-history/History-Country-Western%20-%200301.htm |title = Encyclopedia Of Country, Western, & Gospel Music P0301}}</ref>

In 1971, Wilf Carter was inducted into the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>  Widely acknowledged as the father of Canadian country music, Carter was Canada's first country music star, inspiring a generation of young Canadian performers.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|last=Eder |first=Bruce |title=Wilf Carter Biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/wilf-carter-p30227/biography |access-date=January 14, 2012}}</ref>

== Early years ==

Carter was born in [[Port Hilford, Nova Scotia]], Canada.<ref name="LarkinCountry">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=67/8}}</ref> One of nine children, his father was Swiss.<ref name="Sentinel" /> He began working odd jobs by the age of eight in [[Canning, Nova Scotia]]. He began singing after seeing a traveling Swiss performer named "The Yodelling Fool" in Canning.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Carter left home at the age of 15 after a falling out with his father, who was a Baptist minister.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="canadianencyclopedia">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Wilf Carter |encyclopedia=The Canadian Encyclopedia |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/emc/wilf-carter |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203193330/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/articles/emc/wilf-carter |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 3, 2012 |access-date=January 7, 2012}}</ref>

In 1923, at age 18, after working as a lumberjack and singing with hobos in boxcars, Carter moved west to [[Calgary]], Alberta, where he became friends with [[Pete Knight (rodeo)|Pete Knight]] and found work on the Davis ranch, near Brooks, as a [[cowboy]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> (In 1979, Carter was the grand marshal at the Calgary Stampede.) He made extra money singing and playing his guitar at dances, performing for tourist parties, and traveling throughout the Canadian Rockies.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/> It was during this time that he developed his own yodelling style, sometimes called an "echo yodel" or a "three-in-one".

== Radio years (1930–1940)==
[[File:DownTheOldCattleTrail.jpg|thumb|"Down the Old Cattle Trail" by Wilf Carter]]

Carter performed his first [[Radio station|radio broadcast]] on [[CKMX|CFCN]] Alberta in 1930.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Soon after, he was heard locally on [[CFAC]] and nationally on the [[Canadian Radio Broadcasting Commission|CRBC]]. Two years later, he was entertaining tourists as a trail rider for the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]], who promoted horseback excursions into the [[Canadian Rockies]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Carter soon became very popular in the region.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/>

In 1933, he was hired as an entertainer on the maiden voyage of the British ship S.S. ''Empress''.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Later that year, he stopped off in [[Montreal]] and made his first recording: "My Swiss Moonlight Lullaby" and "The Capture of [[Albert Johnson (criminal)|Albert Johnson]]".<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> After signing with the Canadian branch of [[RCA Victor]], "My Swiss Moonlight Lullaby" became the first hit record ever by a Canadian country performer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://whytemuseum.blogspot.com/2017/06/the-yodeling-cowboy.html |title = The Yodeling Cowboy}}</ref> That same year, Carter also wrote and recorded "[[Pete Knight (rodeo)|Pete Knight]], The King of the Cowboys," which also became a hit.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/>

For seven years (1934-1940) he hosted his own CBS country music radio program in New York City. His announcer was [[Bert Parks]].<ref name=Sentinel>{{Cite web|url=https://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/os-xpm-1985-04-09-0290080140-story.html|title=COMING SHOW ANOTHER 1ST FOR MUSICIAN|website=Orlando Sentinel|date=April 9, 1985 }}</ref> CBS changed his the name to "Montana Slim,"<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> to appeal to American audiences.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/> In 1935, Carter also performed on [[WABC (AM)|WABC radio]]. In 1937, Carter returned to Alberta, where he purchased a ranch. He continued to appear on CBC, NBC, and CBS until CBS dropped him in 1940.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/>

In 1940, Carter seriously injured his back in a car accident in Montana.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> He was unable to perform for much of the decade,<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> but his popularity was sustained by the periodic release of new recordings.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/>

== Recording sessions ==

He had a recording contract with RCA-Victor for five years (1947-1952) and then moved to Nashville where he recorded with Decca from 1954 to 1957.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/wilf-carter-mn0000684917/biography |title = Wilf Carter Biography, Songs, & Albums {{!}} AllMusic| website=[[AllMusic]] }}</ref> At Decca, Carter used [[Owen Bradley]]'s studio, featured a backing band that included [[Chet Atkins]] and [[Grady Martin]]. {{citation needed|date=October 2022}}

He sold his ranch in 1949 and moved his family to a {{convert|180|acre|ha|abbr=on}} farm in [[New Jersey]].{{citation needed|date=October 2022}}

== Touring (1949–1985) ==

In 1949, Carter resumed live performances with tours in Canada and the United States.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> In 1950, he attracted over 50,000 people during a week at the [[Canadian National Exhibition]] bandstand in [[Toronto, Ontario]].

In 1953, Wilf Carter started touring with his own show called, 'The Family Show with the Folks You Know.' His daughters, Carol and Sheila, worked with him as dancers and back-up singers.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

In 1964, Carter performed for the first time at the [[Calgary Stampede]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> He also became one of the most requested guests on the TV show hosted by Canadian country singer [[Tommy Hunter]].

In the 1960s and 70s he toured with [[Hank Snow]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=c--zNXu1v74C&q=carter&pg=PA1924 ''Whispering Pines''], p. 111</ref>

In 1980, Country Music Queen [[Kitty Wells]] and her husband [[Johnnie Wright]] encouraged Carter to tour with them, which was billed as Carter's 80th Birthday Tour. From 1980 to 1985 he toured different parts of Canada.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rocklandsentertainment.com/product/wilf-carter-the-anthology-cd/ |title = Wilf Carter – The Anthology – CD {{!}} Rocklands Entertainment}}</ref>

In 1985, Carter toured with [[Slim Whitman]].<ref name=Sentinel/>

== Recordings ==

Wilf Carter recorded over 40 original and compilation LP records for RCA Victor including ''Nuggets of the Golden West'', ''Christmas in Canada'', ''Songs of the Rail and Range'', ''Songs of Australia'', ''Wilf Carter Sings [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rogers]]'', and ''Let's Go Back to the Bible''. In 1983, he re-recorded many of his most popular songs for ''Fifty Golden Years''.

In 1988, Carter recorded his last album, ''What Ever Happened to All Those Years''. In 1991, at age 86, he made his last concert tour, appropriately called 'The Last Round-up Tour', with shows throughout [[Nova Scotia]], New Brunswick, [[Ontario]], and [[Manitoba]]. He retired the following year, due to his loss of hearing. Wilf Carter died in 1996 in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]], 13 days before his 92nd birthday.<ref>Carter, Wilf. ''The Yodelling Cowboy''. Toronto: Ryerson, 1961.</ref>

== Business ==
In 1952, he moved, this time to [[Orlando, Florida]], where he opened the Wilf Carter Motor Lodge, a venture that lasted only two years.

== Honours and awards ==
In 1971, Wilf Carter was inducted into the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]].<ref name="LarkinCountry"/>

He was inducted into the [[Canadian Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 1984, and the following year, he was inducted into the [[Canadian Music Hall of Fame]] and the Juno Awards Hall of Fame.

He was made an Honorary Chief of the [[Stony Indian]] tribe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cowboycountrytv.com/trailblazers/wilfcarter.html |title = Cowboy Country TV}}</ref>

A video documentary was released in 2000, called ''The Last Round-up: The Wilf Carter Story'', which examined Carter's distinguished career.

== Legacy ==

He wrote hundreds of songs covering a wide range of themes, including traditional country western, cowboy, folk, and hobo songs. His recordings of "Blue Canadian Rockies" and "[[You Are My Sunshine]]" are among the most popular.<ref name="canadianencyclopedia"/> Fellow Canadian country artist [[Ian Tyson]] considers Carter an influence on his music.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eQkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT77|title=Billboard|date=November 23, 1974|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.|access-date=August 5, 2021|via=Google Books}}</ref> Another Canadian artist, [[Stu Davis]], acknowledged the importance of Carter's mentorship early in his career and credited him with securing Davis's first recording contract with Sonora Records in New York.
